frameDefinitions: The words in this frame describe situations in which a Perpetrator forcibly seizes control over a Victim's Vehicle to gain some end.  '' 'French farmers have hijacked a lorry and destroyed its load of strawberries.'
An Entity has ceased to exist.
These are words describing situations in which a Perpetrator wrongs a Victim by taking something (Goods) from them.
An Assailant physically attacks a Victim (which is usually but not always sentient), causing or intending to cause the Victim physical damage.
The Self_mover, a living being, moves under its own direction along a Path.

An individual or group, the Patrol moves through and examines a Ground in order to ensure that it is in a generally Desired_state_of_affairs, particularly that it is safe and contains no dangerous Unwanted_entity.
frameExamples: French farmers have <t>hijacked</t> a lorry and destroyed its load of strawberries.
Half of the team <t>held</t> <t>up</t> the tellers while the others were stationed to report the arrival of police.
As soon as he stepped out of the bar he was <t>set</t> upon by four men in ski-masks.
She <t>walked</t> along the road for a while.
Detective Jones <t>patrolled</t> the northern half of the building.
listRoleDefinitions: This is the person (or other agent) who forcibly seizes control over a vehicle to gain some end.
This is the means of transportation which gets under the control of the perpetrator. Example: The terrorists hijacked <fex name='Vehicle'>the plane</fex>.
This role describes the people that are suffering as a result of the <fen>Perpetrator</fen>'s action.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
Concrete or abstract entity that does not exist after the event.
A point at which the <fen>Entity</fen> (saliently) does not exist.
This is the Place where the <fen>Entity</fen> (saliently) does not exist.
The <fen>Perpetrator</fen> is the person (or other agent) that takes the <fen>Goods</fen> away by force or threats.
The <fen>Victim</fen> is the person (or other sentient being or group) that owns the <fen>Goods</fen> before they are taken away by the <fen>Perpetrator</fen>.
Source is the initial location of the goods, before they change location.
The <fen>Time</fen> indicates when the Robbery occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the Robbery occurs.
This role is the being or entity that is injured by the <fen>Assailant</fen>'s attack.
The person (or other self-directed entity) that is attempting physical harm to the <fen>Victim</fen>.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Assailant</fen> attacks the <fen>Victim</fen>.
This role identifies the place where the <fen>Assailant</fen> makes an assault on the <fen>Victim</fen>.
<fen>Self_mover</fen> is the living being which moves under its own power. Normally it is expressed as an external argument.

<fen>Source</fen> is used for any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion.
In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion.  With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
<fen>Path</fen> is used for any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.  This includes 'middle of path'' expressions.
<fen>Goal</fen> is used for any expression which tells where the <fen>Self_mover</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.

<fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.  Note that this role should not be used for cases when the same phrase could be used with the same meaning with a non-motion target, since these should be annotated with the <fen>Place</fen> FE.
The direction that the <fen>Self_mover</fen> heads in during the motion.
The time when the motion occurs.

The <fen>Place</fen> is the location within which a defined motion takes place.  Any specified or implied  <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> should designate a location contained with the <fen>Place</fen>.  This role can be differentiated from <fen>Area</fen> by the fact that the annotated phrase can be used in the same meaning with non-motion targets.
The person (or group) who inspects the <fen>Ground</fen> to see that it is safe.
The area that the <fen>Patrol</fen> inspects with to ensure its safety.
An entity whose presence would impair the desirability or safety of the <fen>Ground</fen>.
The desired outcome of the patrolling. Normally this constituent is a PP Complement headed by <ment>for</ment>, or a <ment>to</ment>-marked VP Complement.
The desirable state of affairs which the <fen>Patrol</fen> hopes to ensure by visiting <fen>Ground</fen>.
>The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Patrol</fen> examines the <fen>Ground</fen>.
listRoleExamples: The rebels skyjacked a plane <fex>with 89 passangers</fex>.
<fex>Leslie</fex> robbed Kim of her watch.
Leslie robbed <fex>Kim</fex> of her watch.
Leslie and Kim robbed <fex>a bank</fex>
They ROBBED a bank in North Berkeley <fex>last May</fex>.
They robbed a bank <fex>in North Berkeley</fex>.
The mysterious fighter attacked <fex>the guardsmen</fex> with a sabre.
<fex>The mysterious fighter</fex> attacked the guardsmen with a sabre.
<fex>As soon as he stepped out of the bar</fex> he was set upon by four men in ski-masks.
Then Jon-O's forces ambushed them <fex>on the left flank</fex> from a line of low hills.
<fex>Fred</fex> crawled the narrow passage.
The cat ran <fex>out of the house</fex>.
The scouts hiked <fex>through the desert</fex>.
The children skipped <fex>into the park</fex>.
The mouse scurried <fex>about</fex>.
You should walk <fex>south</fex> about a block .
The hitchhikers walked <fex>in the middle of the road</fex>.
<fex>Detective Jones</fex> patrolled the northern half of the building.
Four soldiers with submachine guns patrolled <fex>the room</fex>, and an officer made his rounds at frequent intervals.
Security guards patrolled <fex>for intruders</fex> while the game was in progress.
Patrol all unlit areas <fex>to ensure no one is hiding there</fex>.
All our grounds are regularly patrolled <fex>for safety</fex>.
Officerspoliced the parade grounds <fex>during the Memorial day events.</fex> .

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the last Wednesday of each month
